medium.definition: This medium descriptor indicates that the aquatic medium used in the assay is the actual water of the relevant compartment/zone.
This medium descriptor indicates that the soil medium used in the assay is the actual soil of the relevant compartment/zone.
This medium descriptor indicates that the sediment medium used in the assay is the actual sediment of the relevant compartment/zone.
Combined time dynamic fluid 1) simulated saliva fluid (5mins) then similated gastric fluid is added
Combined time dynamic fluid, first simulated saliva fluid (5mins) then similated gastric fluid is added (2h) and then intestinal fluid is added
E-G-1 screening dispersion test, extended dispersion test
E-G-1 screening dispersion test, extended dispersion test
E-G-1 screening dispersion test, extended dispersion test

medium.descriptor: 'OECD TG318 medium + no NOM (0,1, 10 Ca(NO3)2, pH 4)'
'OECD TG318 medium + no NOM (0,1, 10 Ca(NO3)2, pH 7)'
'OECD TG318 medium + no NOM (0,1, 10 Ca(NO3)2, pH 9)'
'40 mg/L Ca; 6 mg/L Mg; 16 mg/L SO4;0.1 mg/L PO4; + mg/L SRNOM; pH7.5'
medium.definition: E-G-5 Provide name for this composition! Foregs

assay.descriptor: 'High-angle annular dark-field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM)'
'Single Particle Inductively Coupled Plasma Mass Spectrometry'
'Attenuated Total Reflectance Fourier Transform Infrared Spectroscopy'
'Ultrafiltration - Inductivly Coupled Plasma Atomic Emission Spectroscopy'

medium.descriptor: 'OECD TG318 medium + no NOM (0,1, 10 Ca(NO3)2, pH 4)'
'OECD TG318 medium + no NOM (0,1, 10 Ca(NO3)2, pH 7)'
'OECD TG318 medium + no NOM (0,1, 10 Ca(NO3)2, pH 9)'

assay.descriptor: 'Biodegradation wastewater discharge, treated effluent in the mixing zone of surface water'
'Biodegradation wastewater discharge, untreated wastewater that is directly discharged to surface water'
'Screening transformation/dissolution test – sparingly soluble metal compounds'
'Full transformation/dissolution test - metals and sparingly soluble metal compounds'
'Freshwater Alga and Cyanobacteria, Growth Inhibition Test'
'Repeated Dose 90-Day Oral Toxicity Study in Rodents'
'Sediment-water Lumbriculus toxicity test using spiked sediment'

result_endpoint.name: ID_JRC_ID
result_endpoint.definition: The numbering system for the JRC Representative Nanomaterials stored in the JRC Repository has been revised in order to accommodate more nanomaterials and continue to ensure a high level of traceability. Nanomaterials in the JRC Repository are now identified by the following alphanumeric code (JRC ID): JRCNMXXXYYa, where XXXYY is a number that is unique to a single nanomaterial. This alphanumeric code (first column in the table) shall be used in publications to refer to the nanomaterials that have been issued by the JRC Repository. JRCPDZZZKKa is the code used to indicate the pure dispersant (without nanoparticles) in case of nanomaterials provided as dispersion.

endpoint_category.name: PC_COMPOSITION
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID : Composition OHT : Not part of OECD Harmonised Templates A Substance is defined by its composition. The composition of a Substance can consist of constituents, impurities and additives. This section is a repeatable block section. It enables to enter multiple compositions for a Substance, e.g. to allow different profiles of impurities provided it does not change the identification of the Substance. For detailed instructions on how to define the substance composition in IUCLID, see chapter D.4.1 Substance (create and update substance related information)

result_endpoint.name: EP_CONSTITUENT_ROLE
result_endpoint.definition: Indicates the specific role/profile of this constituent in the substance as defined by MATERIAL_KB::ConstituentRole

enum.definition: A 'solid?' 'chemical' representing a substantial part of or the entire 'core' chemistry of a non hollow 'nano-object' ( e.g. 'spheres', 'platelets', 'discs', 'rods', 'wires', 'cubes').
A 'chemical' surrounding a 'core' or other 'shell'. ( not yet clearly distinguished by definition from 'coating' )

A 'chemical' surrounding either a 'core', 'wall', 'shell', 'coating' or 'aggregated' or 'agglomerated'
WIKIPEDIA Functionalization is the introduction of organic molecules or polymers on the surface of the nanoparticle. The surface coating of nanoparticles determines many of their physical and chemical properties, notably stability, solubility, and targeting. A coating that is multivalent or polymeric confers high stability. Functionalized nanomaterial-based catalysts can be used for catalysis of many known organic reactions.
A protein based coating.. (to be deprecated as role) as this overlaps with coating.

A 'chemical' acting as a single or multiple 'walls' in a nanotube. (eg. SWCNT, MWCNT)
Wall (the chemical of a tube)
A solid material representing the matrix material of a composite potentially hosting/containing other dispersed materials.

A liquid substance being the dominant material potentially containing other dispersed, dissolved materials.
Liquid medium (a liquid representing the host medium of a suspension, dispersion, etc.)

A gaseous substance being the dominant material potentially containing other materials dispersed in it (like aerosols)
Gaseous medium (a gas representing the host gaseous medium of an aerosol, etc.)

A solid substance acting as the 'substrate' for another material in roles like: 'film', 'structured film', 'surface bound', 'surface').
Substrate (a solid representing the substrate of film, structured film, etc.)
A layer of material attached to a substrate material
Film (a very thin homogenous layer attached to a substrate material)
Structured film (a very thin structured layer attached to a substrate material)
Surface bound (particulate matter bound to a surface)
Dispersed (particulate matter dispersed in a solid or liquid medium or gaseous medium (aerosol))
Dissolved (dissolved chemical in a liquid or solid medium)
Mixed (a material mixed with other mixed materials)
Layered (a solid layer, layered with other layers) (eg. laminate)
Aggregated (strongly bounded with other particles)
Agglomerated (weakly bounded with other particles)
An unintended chemical being part of the composing material (eg. contaminant)
Deprecated (impurity only)
Container (a substance, containing other materials, substances (glass of a bottle))
Contained (the material/substance/chemical contained by a container material)
Capsule (a substance/chemical the capsule wall is made of)
Encapsulated (a substance/chemical inside the capsule wall)
An intentional introduced impurity to alter certain material properties like electrical or optical properties (new..)
Constituent which is intentionally added to stabilise the substance and only for this purpose
A chemical representing the main constituent of a substance

result_endpoint.name: EP_COMPOSITION_CATEGORY
result_endpoint.definition: Indicates to which composition category the substance or constituent belongs: 'organic compound' ,'organic matter', 'inorganic compound', 'inorganic matter','hybrid material', 'mixture', 'water'

enum.definition: An organic compound is generally any 'chemical' that contains carbon.
Organic matter is matter composed of organic compounds.
An inorganic compound is generally any chemical lacking carbon, so not an 'organic compound' or water.
Inorganic matter is matter composed of solely inorganic compounds.
Hybrid materials are composites consisting of two or more 'chemicals' at the nanometer or molecular level, at least one being 'organic'. (Wikipedia)
any combination of different material categories (eg. ) above the nano or molecular size.

result_endpoint.name: EP_MASS_CONC
result_endpoint.definition: The typical mass concentration of the constituent under consideration within the entire material (sample). [mg/kg]

result_endpoint.name: EP_MOLECULAR_FORMULA
result_endpoint.definition: An expression which states the number and type of atoms present in a molecule of a substance.

result_endpoint.name: EP_PURITY
result_endpoint.definition: Degree of purity (%) (REACH regulation, consolidated version 01.01.2020)

result_endpoint.name: EP_ELEMENTAL_COMPOSITION_MASS_CONC
result_endpoint.definition: Elemental composition expressed as mass concentration.

result_endpoint.name: EP_ELEMENTAL_COMPOSITION_ATOM_PERC
result_endpoint.definition: Elemental composition expressed as atomic percentage (at%)

result_endpoint.name: EP_PHYSICAL_STATE
result_endpoint.definition: Physical state at 20°C and 1013 hPa, enumeration with domain MATERIAL_KB::PhysicalState{gas', 'liquid', 'solid'}

enum.definition: Used to indicate that matter is in its ionic state. eg. Ag+
Used to indicate the substance and all of its constituents are in solid phase. (eg. Ag(s) ) [2381]
Used to indicate a substance is in liquid state. ( e.g. H2O(aq) ) [2038]
Used to indicate a substance is in gaseous state. ( e.g. CO2(g) ) [2830]
The mixed state can only occur if a ‘substance’ is composed of other ‘substances’ in different states.

result_endpoint.name: EP_FORM
result_endpoint.definition: Enumerate like '{solid: particulate/powder'}

result_endpoint.name: EP_ODOUR
result_endpoint.definition: Enumeration with domain MATERIAL_KB::OdourCategory{'ammonia-like', 'biting', 'characteristic of sulfur-containing compounds', 'characteristic of aromatic compounds', 'faint', 'garlic-like', 'odourless', 'pungent', 'slight', 'sweetish','other'}

enum.definition: IUCLID phrase 4759

result_endpoint.name: EP_COLOUR
result_endpoint.definition: Open text for now..??

result_endpoint.name: EP_COLOUR_INTENTSITY
result_endpoint.definition: Enumerate: {dark,.. TBD} see registration dossier ECHA

endpoint_category.name: PC_MELTING
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.2: Melting point/ freezing point OHT 2: Melting point/freezing point

result_endpoint.name: EP_MELTING_POINT
result_endpoint.definition: The melting point is defined as the temperature at which the phase transition from the solid to the liquid state at atmospheric pressure takes place. (OECD TG 102, 1995)

endpoint_category.name: PC_BOILING
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.3: Boiling point OHT 3: Boiling point

result_endpoint.name: EP_BOILING_POINT
result_endpoint.definition: Point at which the vapour pressure of a liquid equals the external pressure acting on the surface of liquid [SOURCE: ISO 11504:2012] The normal boiling point of a liquid is defined as the temperature at which the vapour pressure equals the standard atmospheric pressure 101.325 kPa. (OECD TG 103, 1995)

result_endpoint.name: EP_TRUE_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition: The mass of a particle divided by its volume, excluding open pores and closed pores (BSI). True density also used for liquids and gases.

result_endpoint.name: EP_ABSOLUTE_POWDER_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition:
The mass of powder per unit of absolute volume (BSI). Absolute powder volume: (also called Absolute volume): The volume of the solid matter after exclusion of all the spaces (pores and voids) (BSI).
The mass of powder per volume of solid matter after exclusion of all spaces (pores and voids)

result_endpoint.name: EP_APPARENT_PARTICLE_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition:
The mass of a particle divided by its apparent (particle) volume (BSI). Apparent particle volume: The total volume of the particle, excluding open pores, but including closed pores (BSI).
The mass of a particle divided by the total volume of the particle, excluding open pores, but including closed pores. According to WP3: Apparent particle density EQUALS Skeletal density! (we could decide to delete apparent this one and always use skeletal density)

result_endpoint.name: EP_APPARENT_POWDER_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition:
The mass of a powder divided by its apparent volume (BSI). Apparent powder volume: The total volume of solid matter, open pores and closed pores and interstices (BSI).
The mass of a powder divided by the total volume of solid matter, open pores and closed pores and interstices.

result_endpoint.name: EP_BULK_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition: Bulk density: (also called Bulk powder density): The apparent powder density under defined conditions (BSI). The mass of the particles divided by the volume they occupy that includes the space between the particles (ASTM D5004). The ratio of the mass of a collection of discrete pieces of solid material to the sum of the volumes of: the solids in each piece, the voids within the pieces, and the voids among the pieces of the particular collection (ASTM D3766). for solids only (IUCLID source) The density of a solid is derived from the difference in weight between a sample in air and in a liquid of known density (e.g. water). The density thus measured is only representative of the particular sample employed (bulk density). (OECD TG 109, 2012)

result_endpoint.name: EP_EFFECTIVE_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition:
The effective density of nano-agglomerates in liquid suspension refers to the density of the agglomerate unit, which includes both particles and media components, as opposed to the density of the primary particle, which is simply the density of the raw ENM material (particle effective density) ENM_0000093
Effective particle density: The mass of a particle divided by its volume including open pores and closed pores (BSI).

result_endpoint.name: EP_ENVELOPE_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition: The ratio of the mass of a particle to the sum of the volumes of: the solid in each piece and the voids within each piece, that is, within close-fitting imaginary envelopes completely surrounding each piece (ASTM D3766).

result_endpoint.name: EP_SKELETAL_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition: The ratio of the mass of discrete pieces of solid material to the sum of the volumes of: the solid material in the pieces and closed (or blind) pores within the pieces (ASTM D3766). Ratio of sample mass to skeleton volume (ISO 15901-1:2016, skeleton density) Skeleton volume: volume of the sample including the volume of closed pores (if present) but excluding the volumes of open spores as well as that of void spaces between particles within the bulk sample (ISO 15901-1:2016, source: ISO 12514)

result_endpoint.name: EP_TAP_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition:
The apparent powder density obtained under stated conditions of tapping (BSI).
Nanoreg D2_03 Tap density describes the mass per volume after powder compaction in a cylinder (50 times repeated 25 mm drop of a cylinder onto a rubber pad) or by the use of a Dry Substance Jolting Volumeter (ISO 787).
A known weight of a solid material is placed in a glass graduated (i.e. measuring) cylinder and its volume measured to determine the ‘pour density.’ The cylinder is then raised and allowed to fall vertically through a distance of 25 mm on a rubber pad 50 times (or this may be performed using a Dry Substance Jolting Volumeter as described in ISO 787/11). The volume is measured again to determine the ‘tap density.’ (OECD TG 109, 2012)

result_endpoint.name: EP_THEORETICAL_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition: The ratio of the mass of a collection of discrete pieces of solid material to the sum of the volumes of said pieces, the solid material having an ideal regular arrangement at the atomic level (ASTM). Theoretical density is true density of a material corresponding to the limit attainable through full density products without pores. (https://www.sciencedirect.com/topics/engineering/theoretical-density)

result_endpoint.name: EP_RELATIVE_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition: Relative density is the ratio of the density (mass of a unit volume) of a substance to the density of a given reference material. (dimensionless unit) The relative density (D20/4, density at 20 degrees Centigrade relative to water at 4 degrees Centigrade) may be used to compare different chemicals. (OECD TG 109, 2012)

endpoint_category.name: PC_GRANULOMETRY
endpoint_category.definition:
IUCLID 4.5 Particle size distribution (Granulometry) OHT 5: Particle size distribution (Granulometry)/Fibre length and diameter distribution
A typical order of length scale is: largest dimension > hydrodynamic diameter > volume (or mass) equivalent diameter > Stokes diameter > VSSA equivalent diameter > smallest dimension (Appendix 4).

result_endpoint.name: EP_NOMINAL_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: The indicative particle diameter as provided by the supplier

result_endpoint.name: EP_NOMINAL_LENGTH
result_endpoint.definition: The indicative particle length as provided by the supplier / manufacturer

result_endpoint.name: EP_PRIMARY_PARTICLE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition:
primary particle: original source particle (3.1) of agglomerates (3.4) or aggregates (3.5) or mixtures of the two [SOURCE: ISO 26824:2013, 1.4] (ISO/TS 80004-2:2015)
Primary particles are the original seeds from which particles grow and are therefore an unrelated concept to constituent particles, aggregates and agglomerates. Therefore, the term ‘primary particle’ is irrelevant for the EC NM definition. (JRC Report 2019, An overview of concepts and terms used in the European Commission’s definition of nanomaterial)

result_endpoint.name: EP_CONSTITUENT_PARTICLE_SIZE
result_endpoint.definition: (JRC Report 2019, An overview of concepts and terms used in the European Commission’s definition of nanomaterial)

result_endpoint.name: EP_FERET_DIAMETER_D1
result_endpoint.definition:
Feret’s diameter D1 (minimum distance edge to edge, the minor axis). Minimum diameter D1 corresponds to the ”breadth” of the particle. [ISO 9276-6:2008 8.1.2]
In case of agglomerates/aggregates the minimum Feret diameter (EP_FERET_DIAMETER_D1) refers to the entire agglomerate/aggregate, whereas the maximum inscribed circle (EP_LARGEST_INTERNAL_CIRCLE) does not refer to the entire aggregate, but to the constituent particles of the agglomerate/aggregate ( from the NanoDefine project [21] ).

result_endpoint.name: EP_FERET_DIAMETER_D3
result_endpoint.definition: Feret’s diameter D3 (maximum distance edge to edge, the major axis), Maximum diameter D3 corresponds to the “length” of the particle; [ISO 9276-6:2008 8.1.2]

result_endpoint.name: EP_LARGEST_INTERNAL_CIRCLE
result_endpoint.definition:
Largest internal circle or maximum inscribed circle diameter: it is the diameter of the largest circle that fits inside the virtual envelope of the boundaries of the particle on a 2D image.
In case of agglomerates/aggregates the minimum Feret diameter (EP_FERET_DIAMETER_D1) refers to the entire agglomerate/aggregate, whereas the maximum inscribed circle does not refer to the entire aggregate, but to the constituent particles of the agglomerate/aggregate ( from the NanoDefine project [21] ).

result_endpoint.name: EP_LEGENDRE_ELLIPSE_D1
result_endpoint.definition:
Legendre ellipse D1, (length of the minor axis of the legendre ellipse)
An ellipse with its centre at the particle’s centroid and with the same geometrical moments, up to the second order, as the original particle area. [ISO 9276-6:2008 8.1.2]

result_endpoint.name: EP_LEGENDRE_ELLIPSE_D3
result_endpoint.definition:
Legendre ellipse D3, (length of the major axis of the legendre ellipse)
An ellipse with its centre at the particle’s centroid and with the same geometrical moments, up to the second order, as the original particle area. [ISO 9276-6:2008 8.1.2]

result_endpoint.name: EP_GEODESIC_LENGTH_D3
result_endpoint.definition: Geometrical descriptor, length of the fibre when stretch into a straight line. Provide definition [ISO 9276-6:2008]

result_endpoint.name: EP_GEODESIC_THICKNESS
result_endpoint.definition: Is the thickness of the individual fibre, and therefore <= as the EP_FERET_DIAMETER_D1 Provide definition [ISO 9276-6:2008]

result_endpoint.name: EP_EQUIVALENT_CIRCLE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: Diameter of a sphere having the same projection area as the particle: SQRT( 4 * [Area] / π) (Also used: equivalent circle diameter, ECD) [ISO 9276-6:2008 7]

result_endpoint.name: EP_SURFACE_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: D_surface = diameter of a sphere with the same surface as the particle

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOLUME_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: D_volume = diameter of a sphere with the same volume as the particle (Equivalent volume diameter)

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOLUME_EQ_DISC_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: Diameter of a disc with the same volume as the disc/platelett like particle.

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOLUME_EQ_DISC_THICKNESS
result_endpoint.definition: Thickness of a disc with the same volume as the disc/platelett like particle.

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOLUME_EQ_CYLINDER_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: diameter of a cylinder with the same volume as the fibre like particle.

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOLUME_EQ_CYLINDER_LENGTH
result_endpoint.definition: Length of a cylinder with the same volume as the fibre like particle.

result_endpoint.name: EP_HYDRODYNAMIC_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition:
Hydrodynamic equivalent diameter D_hydro (= diameter of a sphere with the same translational diffusion coefficient as the particle in the same fluid under the same conditions)
equivalent spherical diameter of a particle in a liquid having the same diffusion coefficient as the real particle in that liquid [SOURCE: ISO/TS 80004‑6:2013, 3.2.6]

result_endpoint.name: EP_Z_AVERAGE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: The Z-Average size or Z-Average mean used in dynamic light scattering is a parameter also known as the cumulants mean. It is the primary and most stable parameter produced by the technique. The Z-Average mean is the best value to report when used in a quality control setting as it is deﬁ ned in ISO 13321 and more recently ISO 22412 which deﬁ nes this mean as the ‘harmonic intensity averaged particle diameter’. Z-average size is the intensity weighted harmonic mean size The intensity-weighted mean diameter derived from the cumulants analysis Intensity weighted hydrodynamic diameter. Z-AVE HYDRODYNAMIC DIAMETER (DLS RESULT)

result_endpoint.name: EP_STOKES_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: D_Stokes (= equivalent diameter corresponding to the diameter of a sphere with the same final settling velocity as the particle undergoing laminar flow in a fluid of the same density and viscosity)

result_endpoint.name: EP_AERODYNAMIC_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: The diameter in [nm] of an equivalent spherical particle with unit density and the same settling velocity in air as the particle under consideration. The aerodynamic diameter of an irregular particle is defined as the diameter of the spherical particle with a density of 1000 kg/m3 and the same settling velocity as the irregular particle. (Wikipedia) The diameter of a sphere with unit density that has aerodynamic behavior identical to that of the particle in question; an expression of aerodynamic behavior of an irregularly shaped particle in terms of the diameter of an idealized particle. Particles having the same aerodynamic diameter may have different dimensions and shapes. [https://www.opentoxipedia.org/index.php/Aerodynamic_diameter] [constraint, only relevant if medium.physical_state = gas] The median aerodynamic diameter => MAD

result_endpoint.name: EP_MASS_MEDIAN_AERODYNAMIC_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: Mass Median Aerodynamic Diameter (MMAD) is defined as the aerodynamic diameter [EP_AERODYNAMIC_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER] at which 50% of the particles by mass are larger and 50% are smaller.

result_endpoint.name: EP_SIEVE_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: Sieve D (= equivalent diameter corresponding to the diameter of a sphere passing through a sieve of defined mesh size with square or circular apertures).

result_endpoint.name: EP_ELECTRICAL_MOBILITY_EQ_SPHERE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: Electrical mobility equivalent diameter, defines the size of charged particles with the same electrical mobility or the same terminal migration velocity in still air under the influence of a constant electrical field. [ISO 27891:2015 3.16] ES-DMA result

result_endpoint.name: EP_DISPERSITY
result_endpoint.definition: This index is a number calculated from a simple 2 parameter ﬁ t to the correlation data (the cumulants analysis). The dispersity (PDI) is dimensionless and scaled such that values smaller than 0.05 are rarely seen other than with highly monodisperse standards. Values greater than 0.7 indicate that the sample has a very broad size distribution and is probably not suitable for the dynamic light scattering (DLS) technique. The various size distribution algorithms work with data that falls between these two extremes. The calculations for these parameters are deﬁ ned in the ISO standard document 13321:1996 E and ISO 22412:2008.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DISPERSITY_2
result_endpoint.definition: PDI deﬁned as D(w)/D(n), where D(w) is the mean particle size expressed in a weight basis while D(n) is the mean particle size expressed in a number basis. (CLS)

result_endpoint.name: EP_MODE_COUNT
result_endpoint.definition: The number of intensity peaks dectected. (PEAK = MODE) (ThinkWorks) Perhaps extend this descriptor like EP_INTENSITY_MODE_COUNT

result_endpoint.name: EP_FULL_WIDTH_AT_HALF_MAXIMUM
result_endpoint.definition: The same as HALF HEIGHT PEAK WIDTH??

result_endpoint.name: EP_RADIUS_OF_GYRATION
result_endpoint.definition: RADIUS OF GYRATION (SAXS)

result_endpoint.name: EP_GEOMETRIC_MEAN_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: Is this a relevant endpoint descriptor it seams to lack an indication of the base.. number, mass, volume, surface etc??

result_endpoint.name: EP_DERIVED_COUNT_RATE
result_endpoint.definition: DLS specific (The amount of protons arriving at the detector per second) is expresses in Kcps (Kilo counts per second, which is equivalent to 1000 photons ariving at the detector per second.) Perhaps make descriptor more specific.. EP_DERIVED_PHOTON_COUNT_RATE??

result_endpoint.name: EP_RELATIVE_INTENSITY
result_endpoint.definition: DLS specific?? PERHAPS RENAME in EP_RELATIVE_SCATTERING_INTENSITY

result_endpoint.name: EP_DIMENSION
result_endpoint.definition: Represent the dimension a size is related to. D1, D2 and D3 where D1 is the smallest, D2 is the intermediate and D3 the largest dimension.

enum.definition: D1 is the shortest of three dimensions (x,y,z)
D2 the dimension considered either equal or between D1 and D3
D3 is the longest of three dimensions (x,y,z)

result_endpoint.name: EP_PARTICLE_SIZE_LEVEL
result_endpoint.definition: Indicates which level the size information is related to. Two levels are distinguished: constituent particle level, agglomeration/aggregation level.

enum.definition: The size is related to the primary particle: original source particle (NOTE, the primary particle is not to be mistaken with the constituent particle. (see (JRC Report 2019, An overview of concepts and terms used in the European Commission’s definition of nanomaterial)))
The size data is related to the individual constituent particle either individually present or part of the aggregate/agglomerate.
The size data is related to the entire assembly structure (agglomerate/aggregate) existing out of 1 or more primary constituent particles.

result_endpoint.name: EP_OBSERVATION_SCALE
result_endpoint.definition: ISO/TS 11888:2017(E) atomic scale Mesoscopic (individual) “macroscopic” describes the shape and size of MWCNT aggregates or agglomerates

enum.definition: Observation at the atomic scale
Observation at the individual (non-aggregated) particle level
Observation at the aggregated/agglomerated scale

result_endpoint.name: EP_DmPx_D1
result_endpoint.definition: DmPx_D1, X% of the populations mass lies below this size of the smallest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DmPx_D2
result_endpoint.definition: DmPx_D2, X% of the populations mass lies below this size of the 2nd dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DmPx_D3
result_endpoint.definition: DmPx_D3, X% of the populations mass lies below this size of the largest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DnPx_D1
result_endpoint.definition: DnPx_D1, X% of the populations number lies below this size of the smallest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DnPx_D2
result_endpoint.definition: DnPx_D2, X% of the populations number lies below this size of the second dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DnPx_D3
result_endpoint.definition: DnPx_D3, X% of the populations number lies below this size of the largest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DvPx_D1
result_endpoint.definition: DvPx_D1, X% of the populations volume lies below this size of the smallest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DvPx_D2
result_endpoint.definition: DvPx_D2, X% of the populations volume lies below this size of the second dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DvPx_D3
result_endpoint.definition: DvPx_D3, X% of the populations volume lies below this size of the largest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DsPx_D1
result_endpoint.definition: DsPx_D1, X% of the populations surface area lies below this size of the smallest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DsPx_D2
result_endpoint.definition: DsPx_D2, X% of the populations surface area lies below this size of the second dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DsPx_D3
result_endpoint.definition: DsPx_D3, X% of the populations surface area lies below this size of the largest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DiPx_D1
result_endpoint.definition: DiPx_D1, X% of the populations light intensity lies below this size of the smallest dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DiPx_D2
result_endpoint.definition: DiPx_D2, X% of the populations light intensity lies below this size of the second dimension.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DiPx_D3
result_endpoint.definition: DiPx_D3, X% of the populations light intensity lies below this size of the largest dimension.

endpoint_category.name: PC_VAPOUR
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.6: Vapour pressure OHT 6: Vapour pressure

result_endpoint.name: EP_VAPOUR_PRESSURE
result_endpoint.definition: The vapour pressure of a substance is defined as the saturation pressure above a solid or liquid substance. The SI unit of pressure, which is the pascal (Pa), should be used. (OECD TG 104, 2006)

endpoint_category.name: PC_PARTITION
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.7 : Partition coefficient OHT 7: Partition coefficient

result_endpoint.name: EP_LOG_POW
result_endpoint.definition: The partition coefficient between water and 1-octanol (POW) is defined as the ratio of the equilibrium concentrations of the test substance in 1-octanol saturated with water (CO) and water saturated with 1-octanol (CW). POW = CO / CW As a ratio of concentrations it is dimensionless. Most frequently it is given as the logarithm to the base 10 (log POW). POW is temperature dependent and reported data should include the temperature of the measurement. (OECD TG 123, 2006)

endpoint_category.name: PC_WATER_SOL
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.8: Water solubility OHT 8: Water solubility

result_endpoint.name: EP_WATER_SOL
result_endpoint.definition: The water solubility of a substance is the saturation mass concentration of the substance in water at a given temperature. Water solubility is expressed in mass of solute per volume of solution. The SI unit is kg/m3 but g/l is commonly used. (OECD TG 105, 1995)

result_endpoint.name: EP_DISSOLUTION_RATE
result_endpoint.definition: The amount of substance dissolved (solute) into a solvent over time, expressed as ng/cm2/h

result_endpoint.name: EP_DISSOLUTION_HALF_TIME
result_endpoint.definition: Dissolution expressed as the time needed to dissolve half the mass.

result_endpoint.name: EP_DISSOLUTION_MASS_LOSS
result_endpoint.definition: The mass percentage of substance dissolved (solute) into a solvent per hour (expressed as %/h) (based on dissolution rate definition in OECD Guidance Documents 317 & 318).

result_endpoint.name: EP_INTRACELLULAR_DISSOLUTION_HALFTIME
result_endpoint.definition: H-I-1, H-I-2 => Qualitiative outcome

result_endpoint.name: EP_TRANSFORMATION_D1
result_endpoint.definition: % change in morphology of the smallest dimension, pre versus post incubation transformation. (reduction in size D1?)

result_endpoint.name: EP_TRANSFORMATION_D3
result_endpoint.definition: % change in morphology of the largest dimension, pre versus post incubation transformation. (reduction in size D3?)

result_endpoint.name: EP_TRANSFORMATION_MORPHOLOGY
result_endpoint.definition: % of ??

assay.descriptor: 'Screening transformation/dissolution test – sparingly soluble metal compounds'

endpoint_category.name: PC_SOL_ORGANIC
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.9: Solubility in organic solvents OHT 9: Solubility in organic solvents/fat solubility

result_endpoint.name: EP_SOL_ORGANIC
result_endpoint.definition: The mass fraction of a substance which forms a homogeneous phase with a liquid fat(oil) without giving rise to chemical reactions is defined as fat solubility. The maximum of such mass fraction is called the saturation mass fraction, and this is a function of temperature. The composition of fats will differ from organism to organism and even within a single organism. Since it is desirable to be able to compare results from different laboratories, it is necessary to employ standard fat. This standard fat should be similar in composition and behaviour to materials occurring naturally, and a commercial triglyceride mixture described in the Annex satisfies this requirement, although any other mixtures of triglycerides that give demonstrably comparable results can be used. The saturation mass fraction of a substance should be given in g/kg of standard fat and referenced to 37°C ± 0.5°C. (OECD TG 116, 1981)

endpoint_category.name: PC_SURFACE_TENSION
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.10: Surface tension OHT 10: Surface tension

result_endpoint.name: EP_WATER_CONTACT_ANGLE
result_endpoint.definition: When a liquid does not spread on a substrate (usually a solid), a contact angle (θ) is formed which is defined as the angle between two of the interfaces at the three-phase line of contact. It must always be stated which interfaces are used to define θ. It is often necessary to distinguish between the 'advancing contact angle' (θa), the 'receding contact angle' (θr) and the 'equilibrium contact angle' (θe). (IUPAC Gold Book, https://goldbook.iupac.org/terms/view/C01290)

endpoint_category.name: PC_STABILITY_THERMAL_SUNLIGHT_METALS
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.19: Stability: thermal, sunlight, metals OHT 19: Stability: thermal, sunlight, metals

result_endpoint.name: EP_MASS_LOSS
result_endpoint.definition: Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is conducted on an instrument referred to as a thermogravimetric analyzer. A thermogravimetric analyzer continuously measures mass while the temperature of a sample is changed over time. Mass, temperature, and time in thermogravimetric analysis are considered base measurements while many additional measures may be derived from these three base measurements. TGA provide thus the weight loss [%] or mass loss [g] (of the organic matter) as a function of temperature.

result_endpoint.name: EP_PH
result_endpoint.definition: pH is defined as the decimal logarithm of the reciprocal of the hydrogen ion activity in a solution.( Covington, A. K.; Bates, R. G.; Durst, R. A. (1985). "Definitions of pH scales, standard reference values, measurement of pH, and related terminology" (PDF). Pure Appl. Chem. 57 (3): 531–542. doi:10.1351/pac198557030531.) OECD 122 (Test Guideline) Electrometric determination of pH measures the negative log10 aqueous hydronium ion concentration of ideal solutions. Dimensionless quantity.

endpoint_category.name: PC_DISSOCIATION
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.21: Dissociation constant OHT 21: Stability: Dissociation constant OECD GD 112: Dissociation is the reversible splitting into two or more chemical species which may be ionic. The process is indicated generally by: RX ⇌ R+ + X- and the concentration equilibrium constant governing the reaction is K= [R+][X-]/[RX]

result_endpoint.name: EP_VISCOSITY
result_endpoint.definition: OECD GD 114: Viscosity is the property of a fluid substance of absorbing a stress during deformation which depends on the rate of the deformation. Similarly, the stress can be regarded as the cause which brings about a deformation rate. The shear stress τ and the shear rate D are related by the equation: τ= η D. η is defined as the dynamic viscosity. The SI unit of dynamic viscosity is the Pascal second, [Pa s]. The SI unit of kinematic viscosity (dynamic viscosity divided by the density of the fluid) is the square metre per second, [m2/s].

endpoint_category.name: PC_AGGLOMERATION_AGGREGATION
endpoint_category.definition:
IUCLID 4.24: Agglomeration/aggregation OHT 101: Nanomaterial agglomeration/aggregation
OECD TG318: Process of contact and adhesion whereby dispersed particles are held together by weak physical interactions ultimately leading to enhanced sedimentation by the formation of precipitates of larger than colloidal size (agglomerates) (slightly modified according to 7). In contrast to aggregation where particles held by strong bonds like sinter bridges, agglomeration is a reversible process.

result_endpoint.name: EP_AA_INDEX
result_endpoint.definition: The agglomeration/aggregation index is a unitless quantity. It is here defined as 1– A'/A'', where A' is the mean diameter of primary particles and A'' is the mean diameter of aggregates. (source OHT)

result_endpoint.name: EP_AA_RATIO
result_endpoint.definition: The agglomeration/aggregation ratio is a unitless quantity. It is the ratio of the number of agglomerates to single particles.

result_endpoint.name: EP_FRACTAL_DIMENSION
result_endpoint.definition:
Fractal Dimension (DF) is the power that an equivalent radius of a NP agglomerate scales to in order to scale to its mass. A DF of 3 hence corresponds to a solid sphere (no porosity) and a value of 1 describes a rod.
NP agglomerates can be divided into diffusion limited agglomerates (DLCA) with DF values of approximately 1.8, and reaction limited cluster agglomerates (RCLA) with a DF value between 2.1 and 2.5. (SAX, VCM)

endpoint_category.name: PC_CRYSTALLINE_PHASE
endpoint_category.definition:
IUCLID 4.25: Crystalline phase OHT 102: Nanomaterial crystalline phase
Crystalline (crystal) phase consist of ordered and periodic atomic arrangements (Nature Reviews Chemistry volume 4, pages243–256(2020)).

result_endpoint.name: EP_CRYSTAL_SYSTEM
result_endpoint.definition: A material in which the atoms are arranged in a translationally periodic array in the three dimensions or which are arranged in rotationally periodic arrays in three dimensions (Cullity, 1978, Element of X-Ray Diffraction, Second Edition, Addison-Wesley Publishing Co., Reading, MA, 1978). In total there are seven crystal systems: triclinic, monoclinic, orthorhombic, tetragonal, trigonal, hexagonal, and cubic.

enum.definition: http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_9000022 [58271]
http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_9000029 [58272]
http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_9000031 [58273]
http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_9000032 [58274]
http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_9000033 [58275]
http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_9000034 [58276]
http://purl.enanomapper.org/onto/ENM_9000035 [58277]

result_endpoint.name: EP_SPACE_GROUP
result_endpoint.definition: A space group is the symmetry group of a configuration in space, usually in three dimensions. In crystallography, space groups are also called the crystallographic or Fedorov groups, and represent a description of the symmetry of the crystal. (Hiller, Howard (1986). "Crystallography and cohomology of groups". Amer. Math. Monthly. 93 (10): 765–779. doi:10.2307/2322930. JSTOR 2322930). Crystals can be classified according to 230 space groups and a space group can be referred to by a number or the space group symbol.

result_endpoint.name: EP_MINERAL_NAME
result_endpoint.definition: Name of the mineral.

endpoint_category.name: PC_CRYSTALLITE_AND_GRAIN_SIZE
endpoint_category.definition:
IUCLID 4.26: Crystallite and grain size OHT 103: Nanomaterial crystallite and grain size
A grain consists of a single material, but may be crystalline, or polycrystalline. An individual crystallite consists of a single phase.

result_endpoint.name: EP_CRYSTALLITE_SIZE
result_endpoint.definition: Crystallite size is the size of a single crystal in powder form which contains a single phase.

result_endpoint.name: EP_GRAIN_SIZE
result_endpoint.definition: Grain consists of a single material that may be crystalline or polycrystalline. SI unit for grain size [m].

endpoint_category.name: PC_ASPECT_RATIO_SHAPE
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.27: Aspect ratio/shape OHT 104: Nanomaterial aspect ratio/shape

result_endpoint.name: EP_ASPECT_RATIO_D3_D1
result_endpoint.definition:
Ratio of maximum D3 to minimum D1 Feret diameter (D3/D1), will result in a value >= 1.
Ratio of length to width of a particle. [ISO 13794:1999 2.10]

result_endpoint.name: EP_ELLIPSE_RATIO_D3_D1
result_endpoint.definition: The aspect ratio of the particle’s fitted ellipse, i.e., [Major Axis]/[Minor Axis]. https://imagej.nih.gov/ij/docs/guide/146-30.html PC_GRANULOMETRY::EP_LEGENDRE_ELLIPSE_D3/PC_GRANULOMETRY::EP_LEGENDRE_ELLIPSE_D1

result_endpoint.name: EP_ASPECT_RATIO_D1_D3
result_endpoint.definition: Ratio of minimum D1 to maximum D3 Feret diameter (D1/D3), will result in a value >0 and <= 1. For not very elongated particles. [ISO 9276-6:2008 8.1.3]

result_endpoint.name: EP_COMPACTNESS
result_endpoint.definition:
Degree to which the particle (or its projection area) is similar to a circle, considering the overall form of the particle: [ISO 9276-6:2008 8.1.3]
Compactness = SQRT( 4 * [Area] / π ) / [D3 Feret diameter]

result_endpoint.name: EP_ROUNDNESS
result_endpoint.definition:
Degree to which the particle (or its projection area) is similar to a circle, considering the overall form of the particle: [ISO 9276-6:2008 8.1.3]
Roundness = (4 × [Area]) / (π × [D3 Feret diameter]^2)

result_endpoint.name: EP_CIRCULARITY
result_endpoint.definition:
Circularity, is defined as the degree to which the particle is similar to a circle, taking into consideration the smoothness of the perimeter. This means circularity is a measurement of both the particle form and roughness. Thus, the further away from a perfectly round, smooth circle a particle becomes, the lower the circularity value. Circularity is a dimensionless value.
[ISO9276-6 8.2]
Degree to which the particle (or its projection area) is similar to a circle, considering the smoothness of the perimeter: SQRT( 4π x [Area] / [Perimeter]^2 )

result_endpoint.name: EP_CIRCULARITY_FORM_FACTOR
result_endpoint.definition: Circularity, equal to 4π × [Area]/[Perimeter]^2 ranges from 0 (infinitely elongated polygon) to 1 (perfect circle). https://imagej.nih.gov/ij/docs/guide/146-30.html

result_endpoint.name: EP_SOLIDITY
result_endpoint.definition:
Solidity, S, is the measurement of the overall concavity of a particle. It is defined as the image area, A, divided by the convex hull area, Ac, as given in Equation 9. Thus, as the particle becomes more solid, the image area and convex hull area approach each other, resulting in a solidity value of one. However, as the particle form digresses from a closed circle, the convex hull area increases and the calculated solidity decreases. Solidity is a dimensionless value.
[ISO9276-6 8.2] Measure of the overall concavity of a particle: Solidity = [Area]/ [Ac] where Ac is the area of the convex hull (envelope) bounding the particle

result_endpoint.name: EP_CONVEXITY
result_endpoint.definition:
Convexity, Cx, is a measurement of the particle edge roughness and is defined as the convex hull perimeter, Pc, divided by the actual perimeter, P, as given in Equation 8. Thus, as the surface of the particle becomes rough, the actual perimeter increases, thus lowering the convexity measurement. Convexity is a dimensionless value.
[ISO9276-6 8.2] Convexity Pc / P = where Pc is the length of the perimeter of the convex hull (envelope) bounding the particle []

result_endpoint.name: EP_DYNAMIC_SHAPE_FACTOR
result_endpoint.definition: Provide definition

result_endpoint.name: EP_SHAPE_CATEGORY
result_endpoint.definition: Four shape categories: spheriodal, elongated, platelets, mixed

result_endpoint.name: EP_SHAPE_SUBCATEGORY
result_endpoint.definition: Subcategories of the overall shape category: [Spherical, Pyramidal, Cubic, Star, Orthorhombic, Polyhedral, Tubes, Rods, Discs, Plates]

result_endpoint.name: EP_ASSEMBLY_STRUCTURE
result_endpoint.definition: The assembly structure of the primary particle. MATERIAL:KB::AssemblyStructure{ 'shell-like structures', 'multi-walled', 'nano-onions' , 'multi-layers' , 'hollow structures'} Warning! Combinations are also possible, like

endpoint_category.name: PC_SPECIFIC_SURFACE_AREA
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.28: Specific surface area OHT 105: Nanomaterial specific surface area

result_endpoint.name: EP_SURFACE_AREA
result_endpoint.definition:
extent of available surface area as determined by a given method under stated conditions
Note 1 to entry: For the purposes of this International Standard, the area includes the external surface of a solid plus the internal surface of its accessible macro-, meso- and micropores.
[SOURCE: ISO 15901-1:2006[1], 3.25]
Is this the same as absolute surface area??

result_endpoint.name: EP_MASS_SPECIFIC_SURFACE_AREA
result_endpoint.definition: Absolute surface area of the sample divided by sample mass. [ISO/TS 80004-6:2013 3.6.1]

result_endpoint.name: EP_SBET
result_endpoint.definition: Brunauer, Emmett and Teller (BET), m2/g => the same as EP_MASS_SPECIFIC_SURFACE_AREA

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOLUME_SPECIFIC_SURFACE_AREA
result_endpoint.definition: Absolute surface area of the sample divided by sample volume. (VSSA) [ISO/TS 80004-6:2013 3.6.1] m2/cm3 EP_MASS_EXTERNAL_SURFACE [m2/g] * EP_SKELETAL_DENSITY [g/cm3] => [m2/cm3]

result_endpoint.name: EP_MASS_EXTERNAL_SURFACE
result_endpoint.definition: This is the mass based external surface area relative to the total mass, where the external surface area is the total surface area minus the surface area of the micropores. See, BET VSSA assay WP3

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOLUME_EXTERNAL_SURFACE
result_endpoint.definition: This is the volume based external surface area relative to the total volume, where the external surface area is the total surface area minus the surface area of the micropores.

result_endpoint.name: EP_MASS_MICROPOROSITY_SURFACE
result_endpoint.definition: Surface area of the micropores in the material relative to the total mass. Unit [m2/g].

result_endpoint.name: EP_TITRATOR_VOLUME
result_endpoint.definition: Volume needed to determine the SSA of a material following the Sears method. Unit [ml]. See (Sears) expressed in (ml)

result_endpoint.name: EP_SURFACE_AREA_TO_VOLUME_RATIO
result_endpoint.definition: Surface Area / Volume, a sphere typically has the lowest ratio of all shapes for the same volume.

endpoint_category.name: PC_ZETA_POTENTIAL
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.29: Zeta potential OHT 106: Nanomaterial Zeta potential

result_endpoint.name: EP_ZETA_POTENTIAL
result_endpoint.definition: Zeta Potential–electrokinetic potential: the electric potential at the shear plane of the diffuse double layer. The zeta potential is derived from electro-kinetic phenomena, the movement of the particles in an electric field. The conversion of electrophoretic mobility measurements into zeta potential requires several assumptions about the properties of the double layer.As long as the assumptions are always identical, identical conversions and hence zeta potentials are retrieved. Reporting zeta potentials would require the reporting of the assumptions made to make them comparable. [OECD TG 318] Unit: [mV]

result_endpoint.name: EP_ISOELECTRIC_POINT
result_endpoint.definition: IEP –Isoelectric point: the pH at which the zeta potential or particle mobility in response to an electric field is zero. Only in the absence of specifically adsorbing ions which change the surface charge compared to the pristine surface, the IEP equals the point of zero charge (PZC) [OECD TG 318]

endpoint_category.name: PC_SURFACE_CHEMISTRY
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.30: Surface chemistry OHT 107: Nanomaterial surface chemistry

result_endpoint.name: EP_ATOMIC_COMPOSITION
result_endpoint.definition:
Add to composition..
Atomic composition of the surface chemistry may refer to hyphenating the TGA (in EP_MASS_LOSS) to evolved gas analysis such as mass spectrometry (TGA-MS). This allows quantitative analysis of the polymer compounds in the material. Another common tool is to hyphenate with FTIR for infra red spectrometry (TGA-FTIR). I am not sure if these come under the same endpoint e.g. EP_EVOLVED_GAS_ANALYSIS or if TGA-MS should be under EP_ATOMIC_COMPOSITION whilst TGA-FTIR should be under EP_COMPOUND_CLASS (or something similar). I ask this because they deliver importantly different results, but in effect give you a quantitative measure of the chemical composition of the polymer. See definitions below for more detail. "TGA-FTIR can be compared to spectral reference databases for identifying the chemical class or family of the unknowns. In many cases, the chemistries can be narrowed down to specific compounds" "TGA-MS provides a sensitive method for analyzing TGA gaseous products in detail... Tentative identification of the original gas products can be performed in two steps: (1) assigning the structure of the fragment ions using the mass data, and, (2) correlating the assigned fragment structures with known fragmentation patterns of specific molecules."definitions from https://www.eag.com/techniques/phys-chem/tga-ega/ as an example.

result_endpoint.name: EP_MASS_LOSS
result_endpoint.definition:
Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) is conducted on an instrument referred to as a thermogravimetric analyzer. A thermogravimetric analyzer continuously measures mass while the temperature of a sample is changed over time. Mass, temperature, and time in thermogravimetric analysis are considered base measurements while many additional measures may be derived from these three base measurements.
This is considered part of PC_SURFACE_CHEMISTRY as this technique can be used to measure the % mass loss on heating. This can be used to infer the % mass of coatings in a nanomaterial sample. Example of micro-TGA https://doi.org/10.1021/ac402888v Standards for TGA are ASTM E1131, ISO 11358

endpoint_category.name: PC_DUSTINESS
endpoint_category.definition:
IUCLID 4.31: Dustiness OHT 108: Nanomaterial dustiness
Propensity of materials to produce airborne dust during handling. [ISO 12025:2012 3.2.15]

result_endpoint.name: EP_RESPIRABLE_DUST_INDEX_MASS
result_endpoint.definition: the mass fraction of inhaled particles penetrating to the unciliated airways

result_endpoint.name: EP_THORACIC_DUST_INDEX_MASS
result_endpoint.definition: the mass fraction of inhaled particles penetrating beyond the larynx

result_endpoint.name: EP_INHALABLE_DUST_INDEX_MASS
result_endpoint.definition: the mass fraction of total airborne particles which is inhaled through the nose and mouth.

endpoint_category.name: PC_POROSITY
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.32: Porosity OHT 109: Nanomaterial porosity Porosity or void fraction is a measure of the void (i.e. 'empty') spaces in a material,and is a fraction of the volume of voids over the total volume.

result_endpoint.name: EP_VOID_SPACE_FRACTION
result_endpoint.definition: Porosity or void fraction is a measure of the void (i.e. 'empty') spaces in a material,and is a fraction of the volume of voids over the total volume.

result_endpoint.name: EP_SPECIFIC_PORE_VOLUME
result_endpoint.definition: volume of open pores unless otherwise stated (ISO 15901-1:2016(en))

result_endpoint.name: EP_MODAL_PORE_DIAMETER
result_endpoint.definition: pore diameter of the maximum in a differential pore size distribution curve (ISO 15901-1:2016(en))

endpoint_category.name: PC_POUR_DENSITY
endpoint_category.definition:
IUCLID 4.33: Pour density OHT 110: Nanomaterial pour density IUCLID 5.0 manual 4.34.1.20. Pour density or void fraction is a measure of the void (i.e. 'empty') spaces in a material,and is a fraction of the volume of voids over the total volume. I DON'T THINK THIS IS THE CORRECT DEFINITION... it is the same as POROSITY definition in IUCLID 5.0.. I guess they mixed up pore and pour!!!
Nanoreg D2_03: Pour density, also called bulk or apparent density, is given by the mass per volume that a given powder occupies as poured directly into a container without any further compaction.

result_endpoint.name: EP_POUR_DENSITY
result_endpoint.definition:
Pour density, also called bulk or apparent density, is given by the mass per volume that a given powder occupies as poured directly into a container without any further compaction. Might be equal to PC_DENSITY::EP_APPARENT_POWDER_DENSITY, PC_DENSITY::BULK_DENSITY
A known weight of a solid material is placed in a glass graduated (i.e. measuring) cylinder and its volume measured to determine the ‘pour density.’ (OECD TG 109, 2012).

endpoint_category.name: PC_PHOTOCATALYTIC_ACTIVITY
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.34: Photocatalytic activity OHT 111: Nanomaterial photocatalytic activity

endpoint_category.name: PC_RADICAL_FORMATION_POTENTIAL
endpoint_category.definition: IUCLID 4.35: Radical formation potential OHT 112: Nanomaterial radical/formation potential

result_endpoint.name: EP_OH_RADICAL_FORMATION_POTENTIAL
result_endpoint.definition: Potential of forming hydroxyl radicals. There appear to be no standardised methods or definitions for this (however, see the OECD document ENV/JM/MONO(2016)7).

result_endpoint.name: EP_OXIDATIVE_DAMAGE_PER_DOSE
result_endpoint.definition: The oxidative damage / nmol TEU /l.

result_endpoint.name: EP_BIOLOGICAL_OXIDATIVE_DAMAGE_MASS
result_endpoint.definition: The mass based oxidative damage (mBOD) in nmol TUE/mg => Trolox-equivalent units (TEU), Arnaud Gandon et al 2017 J. Phys.: Conf. Ser. 838 012033

result_endpoint.name: EP_BIOLOGICAL_OXIDATIVE_DAMAGE_SURF
result_endpoint.definition: The surface based oxidative damage sBOD in nmol TEU/m2 => Trolox-equivalent units (TEU), Arnaud Gandon et al 2017 J. Phys.: Conf. Ser. 838 012033

result_endpoint.name: EP_OXIDATIVE_DAMAGE_AUC_MASS
result_endpoint.definition: AUC => Area Under Curve

endpoint_category.name: PC_CATALYTIC_ACTIVITY
endpoint_category.definition:
IUCLID 4.36: Catalytic activity OHT 113: Nanomaterial catalytic activity
In the REACH context this seems to be descriptive rather than any specific measurable quantity linked to a specific assay, i.e. any available studies relevant to the catalytic properties of the nanomaterial are summarised.
Increase in the rate of reaction of a specified chemical reaction that an enzyme produces in a specific assay system. (IUPAC Gold Book https://goldbook.iupac.org/terms/view/C00881)

endpoint_category.name: PC_RIGIDITY
endpoint_category.definition:
Newly introduced Gracious (ThinkWorks)
Rigidity, in the context of this Guidance, is the ability of an elongated particle or platelet to retain its shape, without damage, when subject to mechanical (bending) forces. (ECHA-19-H-14-EN , Appendix for nanoforms applicable to the Guidance on Registration and Substance Identification )

result_endpoint.name: EP_STATIC_BENDING_PERSISTENCE_LENGTH
result_endpoint.definition: Maximum straight length without static bending (SBPL) (ISO/TS 11888:2017 3.1.4)

result_endpoint.name: EP_BENDING_RATIO
result_endpoint.definition: Ratio between mean-squared end-to-end distance and squared contour length. (ISO/TS 11888:2017 3.1.8)

result_endpoint.name: EP_CONTOUR_LENGTH
result_endpoint.definition: Total length of an MWCNT along its axis. (ISO/TS 11888:2017 3.1.5)

result_endpoint.name: EP_BIOLOGICAL_STIFFNESS
result_endpoint.definition: H-I-1

endpoint_category.name: PC_HYDROPHOBICITY
endpoint_category.definition:
Newly introduced Gracious (ThinkWorks)
In the Greek words, hydro means water, philicity means affinity, and phobicity means lack of affinity.A surface is hydrophobic when its static water contact angle θ is >90° and is hydrophilic when θ is <90°. (J. Phys. Chem. Lett. 2014, 5, 4, 686–688)

result_endpoint.name: EP_WATER_CONTACT_ANGLE
result_endpoint.definition:
Perhaps this is already covered in the PC_SURFACE_TENSION category
Method to measure of wettability (and hydrophobicity thus) of solid surface by water via the Young equation. Unit [°].
Water contact angle (WCA) is the angle formed tangential to the water droplet at the air–liquid–solid interface. A WCA less than 90 degree is an indication of a wettable surface; a WCA greater than 90 degree indicates poor wettability. (doi.org/10.1016/B978-0-12-802926-8.00002-1)

result_endpoint.name: EP_PHOTOLYSIS_HALF_LIFE
result_endpoint.definition: Provide definition..

endpoint_category.name: EN_BIODEG_WATER_SCREEN
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 28: Biodegradation in water: screening tests

endpoint_category.name: EN_BIODEG_WATER_SIM
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 29: Biodegradation in water and sediment: simulation tests

endpoint_category.name: EN_DEGR_MODE_IN_USE
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 31: Mode of degradation in actual use

result_endpoint.name: EP_DISPERSION_STABILITY
result_endpoint.definition:
Dispersion stability refers to the ability of a dispersion to resist change in its properties over time.
Ability to resist change or variation in the initial properties (state) of a dispersion over time, in other words, the quality of a dispersion in being free from alterations over a given time scale. [ISO 13097:2013]

endpoint_category.name: EN_BIODURABILITY
endpoint_category.definition: Resistance to clearance by chemical and physical means, like resistance to chemical dissolution [ISO/TR 19057] (Should this be a phychem category endpoint ??) These endpoints might be moved to the PC_WATER_SOL section (wait for confirmation from WP3)

result_endpoint.name: EP_GROWTH
result_endpoint.definition: OECD 215

endpoint_category.name: EC_AQUATIC_INVERT_TOX_SHORT
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 43: Short-term toxicity to aquatic invertebrates

endpoint_category.name: EC_AQUATIC_INVERT_TOX_CHRONIC
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 44: Long-term toxicity to aquatic invertebrates

endpoint_category.name: EC_ALGAE_TOX
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 45: Toxicity to aquatic algae and cyanobacteria

result_endpoint.name: EP_GROWTH
result_endpoint.definition: OECD 201

assay.descriptor: 'Freshwater Alga and Cyanobacteria, Growth Inhibition Test'
'Freshwater Alga and Cyanobacteria, Growth Inhibition Test'
'Freshwater Alga and Cyanobacteria, Growth Inhibition Test'

endpoint_category.name: EC_AQ_PLANTS_NONE_ALGAE
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 46: Toxicity to aquatic plants other than algae

result_endpoint.name: EP_GROWTH
result_endpoint.definition: OECD 221

result_endpoint.name: EP_GROWTH
result_endpoint.definition: OECD 219

assay.descriptor: 'Sediment-water Lumbriculus toxicity test using spiked sediment'

result_endpoint.name: EP_SURVIVAL

endpoint_category.name: HH_GENETIC_IN_VITRO
endpoint_category.definition: OHT 70: Genetic toxicity in vitro gene mutation, chromosomal damage (clastogenicity) and numerical chromosomal damage (aneuploidy)?

endpoint_category.name: HH_BIOPERSISTENCE
endpoint_category.definition: Isn't this the same as EN_BIODURABILITY?? Perhaps also move to PC_WATER_SOL ..

result_endpoint.name: EP_RETAINED_FIBRE_BURDEN
result_endpoint.definition: Retained burden measured in mg particle / g lung tissue, used to calculate NF half-life %

endpoint_category.name: HH_CYTOTOXICITY
endpoint_category.definition: Cytotoxicity (not covered by OHT??) Treating cells with the cytotoxic compound can result in a variety of cell fates.

result_endpoint.name: EP_APOPTOSIS
result_endpoint.definition: The cells can activate a genetic program of controlled cell death (apoptosis).

result_endpoint.name: EP_NECROSIS
result_endpoint.definition: The cells may undergo necrosis, in which they lose membrane integrity and die rapidly as a result of cell lysis.

result_endpoint.name: EP_CELL_VIABILITY
result_endpoint.definition: The cells can stop actively growing and dividing (a decrease in cell viability) => ENM_0000068 number of “healthy” cells within a population

result_endpoint.name: EP_CELL_PROLIFIRATION
result_endpoint.definition: number of actively dividing cells in a population

result_endpoint.name: EP_CELL_VIABILITY_ABSORPTION_450_NM
result_endpoint.definition: Absorption of light (450 nm) expressed in AU???

result_endpoint.name: EP_CELL_VIABILITY_ABSORPTION_540_NM
result_endpoint.definition: Absorption of light (540 nm) expressed in AU???

endpoint_category.name: HH_INFLAMMATION
endpoint_category.definition: Inflammation category (not yet covered by OHT, inhalation IATA)

result_endpoint.name: EP_INFLAMMASOME
result_endpoint.definition: IL-1β concentration (pg/ml)

result_endpoint.name: EP_INVITRO_CYTOKINE_RELEASE
result_endpoint.definition: Cytokine concentration (pg/ml)

result_endpoint.name: EP_CATHEPSINB_RELEASE
result_endpoint.definition: Release concentration pg/ml

result_endpoint.name: EP_CATHEPSINB_ACTIVITY
result_endpoint.definition: Activity x-fold change over negative control..

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VITRO_GRANULOMA
result_endpoint.definition: Development of 3D granuloma in response to long-term in vitro exposure to NF based on model from Sanchez et al 2011. Qualitative Yes/No

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VITRO_GRANULOMA_SIZE
result_endpoint.definition: Mean diameter: µm These might just be endpoint parameters of IP_IN_VITRO_GRANULOMA (to be deprecated)

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VITRO_GRANULOMA_TIME
result_endpoint.definition: Days post exposure These might just be endpoint parameters of IP_IN_VITRO_GRANULOMA (to be deprecated)

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VIVO_CELL_COUNT
result_endpoint.definition: Absolute: #/L Relative: %

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VIVO_NEUTROPHIL_INFLUX
result_endpoint.definition: Absolute: #/L Relative: %

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VIVO_MACROPHAGE_COUNT
result_endpoint.definition: Absolute: #/L Relative: %

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VIVO_CYTOKINE_RELEASE
result_endpoint.definition: Cytokine conc.: pg/mL

result_endpoint.name: EP_IN_VIVO_INFLAMMATION
result_endpoint.definition: #/# animals with minimal, slight, moderate, marked or massive bronchiolar/ alveolar inflammation

result_endpoint.name: EP_LYSOSOMAL_DISRUPTION
result_endpoint.definition: Qualitative Yes|No

result_endpoint.name: EP_FIBROSIS
result_endpoint.definition: Is this an effect endpoint of cytotoxicity or a category on its own?

endpoint_category.name: HH_OXIDATIVE_STRESS
endpoint_category.definition: Oxidative stress is caused by the presence of any of a number of reactive oxygen species (ROS) which the cell is unable to counterbalance. The result is damage to one or more biomolecules including DNA, RNA, proteins and lipids. Oxidative stress has been implicated in the natural aging process as well as a variety of disease states: ENM_0000037

result_endpoint.name: EP_RFU_CHANGE
result_endpoint.definition: Change in RFU (Relative Fluorescent Unit)

result_endpoint.name: EP_TNF_A_RELEASE
result_endpoint.definition: Release of cytokine TNF-Α (see ELISA assay)

result_endpoint.name: EP_INVITRO_BARRIER_INTEGRITY
result_endpoint.definition: NANoREG D5.03 DR, SOP 03 Ohm/cm2

endpoint_category.name: HH_LUNG_DEPOSITION
endpoint_category.definition: Newly introduced IATA H-I-1 (perhaps move as HH_LUNG_DEPOSITION?)
